Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population. The study included more than 92,000 respondents, including more than 84,000 adults who were 18 and older.
Document Sources.Source Justification: widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "There is a chilling effect," said Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification. "There is an unsafe and intimidating environment around existing as trans in society, and definitely in being able to go to the polls safely and cast a ballot."
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "Trans votes count," said Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund. "I think the big takeaway is that our community is really trying to come out and make a difference through the democratic process."
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "They won't stop me, but I can see how it would stop others," she said. "It is almost certainly stopping some people from showing up at the polls."
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver's license, according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law
